channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Ukraine war: Snake Island and battle for control in Black Sea
item.description: This rocky outcrop has been fiercely contested for weeks and has vital strategic importance.

item.title: Al Jazeera reporter killed during Israeli raid in West Bank
item.description: Israel and the TV channel trade accusations over who was to blame for shooting Shireen Abu Aqla.

item.title: Sri Lanka crisis: Ex-PM flees to naval base as arson attacks spread
item.description: Troops have orders to shoot looters on sight as the president vows to end unrest over the economic crisis.

item.title: Hong Kong cardinal Joseph Zen arrested under China's security law
item.description: Senior Catholic Cardinal Joseph Zen is a long-time critic of the Chinese government.

item.title: Covid mask rules relaxed for EU air travel
item.description: Masks will no longer have to be worn on EU flights and in airports from next Monday, new guidance says.

item.title: Sedition law: India's Supreme Court puts controversial law on hold
item.description: The Supreme Court pauses a colonial-era sedition law that critics say is used to stifle dissent.

item.title: US price rises ease for the first time in months
item.description: The prices of clothing and used cars fell, but inflation remains at a 40-year high.

item.title: Democrats push doomed bid for federal abortion law
item.description: A bill to make the right to abortion a national law is likely to fail, but could have political weight.

item.title: Shanghai moves to impose tightest restrictions yet
item.description: For the next few days, no commercial food deliveries are allowed, and hospital access will be restricted.

item.title: Elon Musk would reverse Donald Trump's Twitter ban
item.description: He says Twitter's decision to ban the former US president was "morally wrong and flat-out stupid".

item.title: Are Sweden and Finland going from neutral to Nato?
item.description: It would be a historic shift if they do and Russia is vehemently opposed to the change.

item.title: Archive sheds new light on Tutankhamun discovery, 100 years on
item.description: An exhibition in Oxford tells how Howard Carter's team excavated the pharaoh's tomb 100 years ago.

item.title: Grenada: Confronting my familyâ€™s slave-owning past
item.description: The BBC's Laura Trevelyan travels to the island of Grenada to investigate her family's slave-owning past.

item.title: Australia election 2022: What will the vote mean for climate policies?
item.description: The outcome could be very significant for the climate, says one of the country's top scientists.

item.title: The 'jockstrap' that revolutionised women's sports
item.description: The sports bra is honoured as a serious invention. The women behind its creation are chuffed.

item.title: From India to UK: An immigrant's snapshots from 1950s
item.description: The lives of Coventry's South Asian immigrants are recorded in Maganbhai 'Masterji' Patel's photos.

item.title: Quentin Sommerville: BBC on patrol with the soldiers pushing Russia back
item.description: The BBC's Quentin Sommerville spends a week with Ukrainians liberating towns north of Kharkiv.

item.title: Eurovision 2022: Emotions run high as Ukraine's Kalush Orchestra qualify for final
item.description: Ukrainian fans celebrated in Turin as the Kalush Orchestra cement their position as favourites to win.

item.title: â€˜If I die no-one will knowâ€™: Covid and Hong Kongâ€™s 'cage men'
item.description: The Omicron variant overwhelmed the city's healthcare system resulting in many deaths.

item.title: Ukraine war: From fighting the Nazis with the Soviets, to fleeing from Putin's war
item.description: A Ukrainian Jew who once fought the Nazis with Russia says he had to flee to escape Putin's war.

item.title: Violence as protesters take to the streets in Sri Lanka
item.description: The unrest comes as Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa resigns, amid a deepening economic crisis.

item.title: Joly Germine: Haitian gang leader indicted over missionary abductions
item.description: Joly Germine allegedly directed the kidnappings of 17 Christian missionaries from a Haitian prison.
